text: What in the hell did they do to this story?Â  Why did they bother calling it The Giver when it is nothing like the book?Â  I mean they could have just made a deal with Lowry to steal the only elements they used from her book - bicycling utopian community, a person called the Giver who holds memories of a less sanitized but more colorful past, a black-and-white world turned to color by seeing these memories - and then called it whatever the hell they wanted.Â  Instead, they made people who liked the book falsely believe they were making a movie of it.Â  Well, I hope Ms. Lowry made enough money from this.Â  I've lost respect for her greenlighting this garbage, though.

text: This is exactly like Percy Jackson and The Lightening Thief, a good book turned into a bad movie. It looks nothing like the book. For one, Joan is not 17, he's 12. And this is very important for the story, too, considering TWELVES get their assignments at that age. Two, Fiona and Jonas never fall in love nor kiss, and he never convinces her to not take the stirrings. This is just a cheap change to the book to turn it into a cheesy love story. Three, it seems like there aren't any assignments at all which is the ENTIRE point of the story.  The Giver also never calls himself that (the giver) like everyone knew, he just gave Jonas that name to call him. I apologize if I'm coming off as harsh, but this seriously just pisses me off. I'm sick of stupid people making movies "based off a book" and it's completely entirely not in anyway the book. They just took the idea of the "looks perfect but not really perfect" community, the names of the characters and SOME of the looks of the characters.Â

text: Problems I have spotted Â 1. Jonah's too old, He's supposed to be twelve. Â 2. They're trying to make this look like the Hunger Games (which was awesome) and Divergent (which sucked) by ripping them off. Â 3. They're putting in new characters, which wouldn't be much of a problem were it not for the fact that: Â 4. They're changing the personalities of existing characters.Â  Â 5. They appear to have taken out the part where the dad kills the small twin in an effort to make this "kid friendly" despite the fact that this is in my old middle school's reading list, Â 6. They've turned the whole thing into an action movie, Â 7. They appear to have changed the relationship between the Giver and Jonah, Â 8. They changed the storyline to involve Fiona more and have her return Jonah's feelings. Â 9. Asher's a pilot now for some reason and an apparent rule breaker. Â 10. I saw no mention of Gabriel anywhere.  All in all, the already low quality of the film sinks even deeper when the butchering of the book is taken into consideration. C- for effort. Awesome books has been turned into a generic "Adventure Teen" film. Canonfodder for the film industries. Will watch with a cyanide pill in my pocket.

text: The Giver was my favorite book that we had to read in School, in fact it's the only one I enjoyed enough to actually buy and re-read.Â  It was a different kind of story, it wasn't out to be a grand spectacle where you left your brain at the door for explosions and chase scenes.Â  Hollywood is filled with enough of that.Â  I am honestly fearful that this movie is going to be bad or really generic and I really hope that I'm wrong.Â   So far Jeff Bridges as The Giver is the only appealing part of the film.Â  The futuristic setting is unneeded, the seemingly forced romance and yet again casting 20 year olds for pre-teens just ruins the more pure sense of these kids being unaware of how controlling and lifeless their lives are.Â  This looks like it's scrapping the best of what The Giver was and updating it for people who can't think or be bothered to read a slow paced book that makes you think and wonder.

author: Fauna Magazine

text: I JUST GOT DONE READING THE BOOK AND I FELL IN LOVE. I STARTED READING JUST A COUPLE OF HOURS AGO AND WAS SUCKED RIGHT IN. I read it willingly! Was not assigned to it at all. What I love about The Giver is that it is the perfect coming of age novel. I love it so so so so much. I also knew the movie was going to be made.. so I checked out the trailer, and have come to the conclusion that this is a travesty to the masterpiece that is The Giver. I am in a state of shock. Not all books should be turned into a movie, clearly. The book is such a great one, but trying to turn it into the next Hunger Games is an insult and frankly a slap in the face to Giver fans and Lois Lowry. It's simply not that kind of book. I just hope they don't completely ruin the novel and at the very least leave the underlying themes in.

text: I love this book, it is one of my favourite pieces that I have ever read. Yet, I am very unhappy with how they will be making the movie. In the book their world was not written to be extraordinarily advanced,Â now this movie looks and feels like every other dystopian film (Hunger Games, Divergent, etc., both series written to be futuristic). It would have made a much larger impact had it been set like it was supposed to, with technology not very different from ours, now it just sort of falls into the crowd of movies with such technology. Second, Jonas is supposed to be young, heÂ is supposed to be around 13-15, so are many of the other characters he interacts with (his age is vital to the plot). Third, they take pills not injections.Â Also, what is with those airplanes/fighter jets?Â It looks to be an interesting rendition, though it fails when it comes to staying true to the book, or even following the basic plot.Â

text: Seeing as I have recently read the book, I am confident in saying that the movie looks great. For everyone saying that it's not staying true to the book, keep in mind that the book was roughly 170 pages. In creating a movie, they would need more elements and more events to keep the viewer interested. If they took those 170 pages, we'd be lucky if we saw an hour. I think that by keeping elements introduced to us in the book and then incorporating things that could very likely happen in that world it'll make for a great movie.

text: No...no no no no! This totally deviated from the purpose of The Giver! The book has an entirely different message and meaning. This is just about a revolution to fit The Hunger Games and Divergent craze. I mean, I understand book to movie adaptations aren't always the same: Harry Potter for instance. But for the most part, by using the same name of the book, they try to keep true to the story line. Here, they completely missed the mark. At least they could rename it or state that they took inspiration from the book or something. I don't know...maybe it's just hitting closer to home than it should since this book is absolutely wonderful.Â

text: I think the only way I'm going to be able to enjoy this movie is to just accept that it's not going to be like the book at all. And even though I was upset about it before I'm going to take this movie for what it is. It does look really good and it fits right in with the hunger games and divergent movies that we've been seeing in the past few years. This is not going to be the story I fell in love with in the 7th grade. This actor looks way too old and in the book Jonas is 11/12 years old....ELEVEN. And yes he liked a girl but it was not this dramatic love story that they're doing for these teenage girls who want another twilight. But ya know what that's okay. My long ass point is I'm gonna stop comparing the 2 and just enjoy the movie, because let's be real. If they were to do this movie exactly like the book their target audience of teenagers wouldn't go see this movie because it wouldn't be about an attractive 16 yr old trying to save humanity blah blah, (we've seen this movie 5x already)

text: I'm not normally one of those people that are like oh this movie is horrible it ruins the book it's nothing like the book it's shit. I normally appreciate the difference b/w book and movie but I'm actually quite angry about this movie adaption tbh. The giver is my #1 favourite novel. It was one of the few original if not the original dystopian novels and this movie is trying to turn it into the hunger games and the Divergent series and that's making me angry. The whole point of the Giver is that it is NOT an action/thriller, it's meant to be a drama. It's meant to be innocent and naive not about Jonas finding love and rebelling. After the first half of the novel he doesn't even really talk to his friends after that. This is supposed to be Jonas' internal journey. And it's making me angry that 1. The movie is making the Giver seem like some vindictive mentor that wants to take down the council which is not necessarily true. Yes he disagrees with what the town is doing but he's too weak and too old to want to do anything. In my eyes he was always a gentle and nice man and the Giver in this movie seems mean and unpleasant. He seems unforgiving and cold. 2. The council is getting suspicious of Jonas when in the novel the council never even noticed what Jonas was doing. Especially since the Giver ultimately has more power than the council and he always gives the council guidance. 3. Jonas doesn't tell anyone about anything that the Giver has taught him except for when he plays war with his friends and tells his sister about animals but those are the few times he slips up and realizes it's better to not inform anyone around him about what he knows. 4. Jonas is 13 and he doesn't fall in love with the red headed girl and ever try to save her 5.The main reason that Jonas "rebels" or leaves is because of his younger brother. He doesn't want his younger brother to have to ever endure the pain of the memories. 6. Only light eyes people are supposed to be able to recieve the memories unless the person with the memories dies or if they run away.Â   I just don't like that they're trying to turn this amazing novel into something completely different. Most movie adaptions stick to the same plot but they remove things or change some endings but this movie just ignoring the original storyline all together and adding in things that never existed in the first place and that is why I'm mad because it really isn't the Giver. If people watch this movie and end up reading the book they will be sadly dissapointed with the novel because the movie is making this book seem like a young adult fiction or something.

text: In my opinion, this great book has been utterly butchered by Hollywood. The movie could be good: nice acting, dynamic characters and storyline, etc., but the fact that the movie is different from the book turns me off. The producers turned the Giver into your typical, generic dystopian teen novel. Another attribute that ruins the film.   Reading the comments, quite a few of you seem to believe that the movie will be better than the book. You seem to have a different taste in 'books' than others who enjoy the Giver as a novel. The Giver as a novel is for one audience, while the film adaption is for a completely different audience. So it's either one or the other; I highly doubt anyone could like both. They're just too... different.

text: I like reading The Giver and I have read a chapter of Divergent very different.  They are not similar at all. Books like Fahrenheit 451,  1984, The Hunger Games and other books similar to society screwing people over. The most similar things about the books I have read so far is that there is ALWAYS one PROTAGONIST who has to defeat the odds and find a way to help the people, but than at the end they always become isolated from society because they are different from all the pain they have endure. If anyone wants to say the recent movies like the Hunger Game, Divergent, and The Giver have similar plots it does but all the main characters in each book have different scenario, personally and situations they must overcome.   My thoughts on The Giver trailer it's different from the book of course. Jonas isn't twelve in the movie for some odd reason even though they hammered that age pretty hard in the book. They probably made him look like this for Teen girls to watch another pretty boy. Gabriel in the movie of course his so adorable. They made Jonas more talkative towards Fiona and Asher. Even though in the book he distance himself from them because of the pain he endures. Maybe the director wanted us to see how close Jonas can be in the movie.  Not too bad, I am excited how this movie will develop.  :)

author: John L

text: The Giver is the only excellent dystopian children's novel I know about; I read it in middle school. Jonas in the book is only 12 years old.Â The Giver's memories are beautifully written, and don't shy from the truth. The descriptions of the horrors of war and especially the descriptions of pain being experienced were really, really deep things to read as a child, and I'm glad that I was able to read them.  The color thing is one of the most satisfying mid-book twists I've encountered. You didn't know they couldn't see color until he starts seeing it as a result of the memories of the past. Way to spoil it, trailer.Â   You also didn't know they were killing people. The book is written so that it seems to be set in a utopia, and through the Giver's memories and revelations you gradually learn that this is not quite the case.  It wasn't an "action" novel, but a slow-paced one. The future they live in isn't fancy and high tech, except where needed as a method of control. Society is boring and peaceful. The book's focus is on the highly charged, emotional descriptions of Jonas experiencing the memories, and his horror at realizing the truth about the world he's in and how it operates, and, most importantly, what it's missing: love.  I won't spoil the details (it would be rude, and you've all been spoiled enough) but Jonas's final act in the book is one bourne out of this missing love, that he comes to appreciate through his experience of it in The Giver's memories. It's a really sweet, and yet desperate act.  The movie looks like it's suffering from blockbuster-itis. Shiny, actiony, and they spoiled all the twists for you. I'm sure it's a fun show in its own right, but I doubt it can capture the elements that made The Giver such a beautiful experience.  Of course, a big part of what makes the book special is that we read it as kids. Things you do as kids really stick with you, you know? It influences you.

text: I wonder if good actors intentionally sign up for movies like this which take only the name and a few key ideas. Like, I'd be willing to bet that they had to at least have read the book since it's part of the canon of dystopian literature.  I understand there are people who will watch and enjoy the movie regardless, but for the few of us that will innately judge the movie against the book since it attempts to be an adaptation...are actors part of that crowd and don't care? Or maybe they've actually never read the book and just said, "Hey, this is an interesting story. I'd like to be a part of this." Do you think any actors outright refuse to participate in loose (being an understatement) adaptations based on similar views?

text: The film is so much more different to the way it is presented in this trailer. I think that I'm in the opposite position to most of the people commenting on this trailer as I have never read the book by Lois Lowry and I sat and watched this movie this morning. The film by Philip Noyce totally had me enthralled from start to finish. I think that Meryl Streep, Jeff Bridges andÂ Brenton Thwaites were perfectly casted. I just felt for Jonas and how the whole film was a metaphor for breaking free. This film was filmed so elegantly and the use of black and white / colour was perfect. Its not trying to be an action flick or fantasy film but a good analysis of society and the huge overstatement being made about the need to over protect everything. The music was amazing and I couldnt believe that taylor swift was in the movie until I saw her name in the credits. FORGET The Hunger Games. FORGET Divergent / Insurgent. The Giver is none of those. It is not even trying to be like them. Think Pleasantville meets The Truman Show. I know people have said that the novel is better than the film but the movie has inspired me now to read the novel.

text: For some reason I feel as if the trailer makes it seem like some horror story because of the music (just my opinion), but for some of you guys if you are wondering what the movie was like or what it was about, I'll tell you and btw this is spoiler alert. If you fully read the book first then you would realize that in the movie of "The Giver" they skip many scenes like Jonas seeing color from an apple and goes straight to Jonas wondering about his ceremony. He tells us about his community and his best friends, Fiona and Asher. The next day he goes straight to the ceremony of the twelve but in the movie there was romance associated and added so Jonas and his friends were actually probably 16-18 years old, not 12. Then it's all pretty much the same as the book, the elder chief calls everyone except Jonas then says she has made a mistake and ask for apology. She then announces that Jonas is The Reciever and they recite his name. After that he was sent to The Giver to recieve memories and the next day he said he saw his best friend, Fiona, and realized she had red hair. He started to feel affections towards Fiona and tried to pass his memory to Fiona but he had failed to and so she didn't see color. He went around showing his best friends and other people his training which he wasn't allowed to and was kept an eye on by the elder cheif 24/7. Then he learns about music and Rosemary, the past Reciver who was failed as a Reciver Â and died from being released which actually means getting a poisonous injection and you die. He then wants to run away from his community but immedietly escaped with Gabriel which he wasn't actually suppose to run away with but did because he heard from his father that Gabriel was going to be released which meant he was going to die. He got the help from Fiona and at that time Fiona loved Jonas because she had feelings after not getting her daily shots which Jonas had told her to do but his other best friend, Asher, did not help him and tried to stop him because he felt obligated that it was the right thing to do. Jonas then escapes and causes a tantrum for the elder chief and his friend Asher tracks him down but lets him go because he is his best friend. He then lies to the elder chief that he had killed and gotten rid of Jonas(and Gabriel). Jonas couldn't make it anymore until he saw the sled that he remembered from his first training session of recieving memories. Jonas slies down the sled along with Gabriel and then pass the existence of boundary and everyone is safe. Fiona wasn't released and so wasn't The Giver and everyone recieved back memories of the good and bad of the past and emotions too. Jonas is left finding a house and hears music but perhaps it was an echo...(I know, I hate cliffhangers too).

text: Am I the only one who think that this isn't necessarily a dystopian future? Its not utopian either, but I feel like a good deal of the aspects that compose the society in this book/movie aren't all bad. No one is poor, no one is sick, no one is alone, no one suicidal. Isn't that a good thing? Maybe I'm being unreasonable and in real life it wouldn't work nearly as well, especially if you dropped some of the worst components (e.g. killing people), but in the fictional world everyone is treated equally and given equal rights. Even the people in the government aren't significantly more prosperous then they average citizen. Yes, choice is vertically non existent, but is that really such a bad thing if everyone is happy and healthy? In real life I don't think it would be necessary to strip people of their emotions and their  ability to see colour and without that aspect I feel like the world of the giver might be, if not a utopia, then still superior to many possibilities. Please respond...

text: I seriously have given up sequels in a book to movie adaptations because of what people say:   â€œThis will never live up to the booksâ€ â€œHer hair is differentâ€ â€œHeâ€™s not what I imagined him to be likeâ€ â€œThey got the wings all messed upâ€ â€œWhy does this remind me of Twilight?â€  (These are from other movies)  The truth is, I kinda enjoy little twists so that it adds a little excitement.   A tip for whoever plans on making sequels in a series book to movies:  FINISH THE DANG MOVIE PROPERLY. END IT WITH NO CLIFF HANGERS PLSS.  Because people like me would cry for a â€œno happy endingâ€ or a â€œthereâ€™s more outside this areaâ€ or â€œweâ€™re taking you somewhere with no clue to where theyâ€™re going.â€  Because we all know that there will be no sequel!!! Mainly because of a book follower fanatic. I know that a lot of people probably donâ€™t think that a certain movie doesnâ€™t deserve to have a sequel.   BUT DIDâ€™nâ€™t ANYONE THINK OF WHAT OTHER PEOPLE WHO HAVENâ€™T READ THE BOOKS THINK OF THE MOVIE.   Iâ€™m sorry for my ranting I just really wanted a sequel of â€˜THE GIVER, THE FALLEN, MORTAL INSTRUMENTS, and etc.â€

text: So this is my thought on how the movie should have looked from the information we got in the book  First of, the homes are not futuristic but they have advanced technology. Secondly this takes part in a futuristic world with knowledge far surpassing ours, that would be controlling the weather, make memories something that you can control and much more. In the book â€œIâ€ didnâ€™t see any information that could hint there being a wall or a drop around the city. I think it just was normal nature with animals and waterfalls, hills and cityâ€™s and so on.  The world is obviously shaped from war or similar, and thatâ€™s is why they did all those rules and things to keep the citizens safe.   I could explain more, but I read this book in one day as a school project and all this is from my memory and I could probably create a similar world that the author was trying to get.   But donâ€™t take my word, this is just what I think from what I got in the book...   Now when I think about it. My book may have been a little bit different but I donâ€™t think so
